boat.construction_details: Carvel, mahogany on oak with a teak deck. She has a long keel and a clipper bow.

for_sales.sales_text:
Built by John Brown in 1967, Anjak  is a unique 32’ (plus 8’ bowsprit) vessel. Rigged for easy single-handed sailing with lightweight duradon sails in excellent condition. Also various other sails including spinnaker. Long-range fuel tank (approx 10 gallons) and with a draft suitable for the French canals, for which the mast being stepped on deck is easily removed.

Carvel hull, mahogany on oak construction with teak laid decks, open cockpit.

A major overhaul and renewing service was carried out in 2010/11, including the fitting of a new 21hp Nanni engine (less than 20 hours use), new stainless water tank, long–range fuel tank, stainless rigging and many other improvements (details on request).

Included in the Sale

21 hp Nanni diesel engine (2010), water cooled, shaft driven 3 blade propeller, 2 batteries, 2 kedge anchors, Cobra Dsc radio (2010), Garmin 12 channel GPS (2010), Seafarer 700 echo sounder, Richie & Plastimo compasses, extensive collection of charts, 2 bilge pumps: manual & electric (Rule-mate 500 submersible), navigation lights, Plastimo Atlantic gimballed gas cooker with oven, grill & two burners, electric coolbox, crockery, cutlery and cooking pans.

Sails (all in good condition)

1 Mainsail, Red Duradon, 2008
1 Foresail, Red Duradon, 2008
1 Jib, white
1 Genoa, DM3 McMillan/Sheppard, 2002
1 Spinnaker, Hof Fenster
1 Staysail, white
1 Genoa, Jeckells

Throughout Mick Tyrrell’s 25 years of ownership he has thoroughly maintained her in excellent condition and continually improved her facilities. The quality and competency of my husband’s craftsmanship was excellent and well respected by those who knew him. Sadly Mick died from cancer in December 2012, hence the reason for selling. Since then I have continued to maintain her good condition, employing a professional to carry out re-painting and repairing as necessary.

boat.full_description:
'Anjak' was home built in 1967/8 and the W Atkin design was stretched from 27' to 32' with the rig changed from schooner to cutter. Her builder, John Brown, owned her until 1985.

She is rigged for easy single handed sailing and has a deck stepped mast and shallow draft suitable for the French canals. The internal layout designed and fitted by Mick Tyrrell, is extremely spacious and practical. With multiple easy-access storage cupboards, the full 9’ beam cabin top allows for plenty of storage, with 5’10” standing headroom throughout the main living space. This ‘tardis’ effect has to be seen to be appreciated. 'Anjak' has four comfortable full-size berths with one that easily converts to a double, making five in total. The toilet compartment has a solid door with hot/cold washing facility.

The roomy cabin has a comfortable cosy atmosphere, with heat and light created by wall fixed gimballed oil lamps. The decks and the wide non-slip cabin top provide a very uncluttered area that is easy to negotiate when working and spacious for relaxing on.

Throughout Mick Tyrrell’s 25 years of ownership he has thoroughly maintained 'Anjak' in excellent condition and continually improved her facilities.

'Anjak' won many races during membership of the Medway Cruising Club, and given her owners, Mick and Hazel Tyrrell much pleasure sailing around the Medway and east coast area and beyond.
